dictionary.phrase: the greatest thing since indoor plumbing
dictionary.definition: Rur. the most wonderful invention or useful item in a long time.  As far as I’m concerned, this new food processor is the greatest thing since indoor plumbing. Joe thinks Sally is the greatest thing since sliced bread. You can tell just by the way he looks at her.

dictionary.phrase: the greatest thing since sliced bread
dictionary.definition: Rur. the most wonderful invention or useful item in a long time.  As far as I’m concerned, this new food processor is the greatest thing since indoor plumbing. Joe thinks Sally is the greatest thing since sliced bread. You can tell just by the way he looks at her.

Hello and good wishes. (A bit stilted.) _ “Greetings and felicitations! Welcome to our talent show!” said the master of ceremonies.  Bill: Greetings and salutations, Bob! Bob: Come off it, Bill. Can’t you just say “Hi” or something?

Hello and good wishes. (A bit stilted.) _ “Greetings and felicitations! Welcome to our talent show!” said the master of ceremonies.  Bill: Greetings and salutations, Bob! Bob: Come off it, Bill. Can’t you just say “Hi” or something?

something useful or needed.  Bob bases the novels he writes on his own experience, so everything that happens to him is grist for the mill.  Ever since I started making patchwork quilts, every scrap of cloth I find is grist for the mill.

something useful or needed.  Bob bases the novels he writes on his own experience, so everything that happens to him is grist for the mill.  Ever since I started making patchwork quilts, every scrap of cloth I find is grist for the mill.

to feel around blindly for someone or something.  In the darkness, he groped about for his glasses.  Fran groped for the light switch and found it.
to feel around blindly for someone or something.  In the darkness, he groped about for his glasses.  Fran groped for the light switch and found it.
Euph. an unpleasant experience. This job has been a growth experience for me. I’ve learned so much.  Jim said that his trip to Mexico turned out to be a real learning experience.

to lead or escort someone on a tour of something or some place. Please let me guide you around the plant, so you can see how we do things here.  I would be happy to guide you around.
to lead or escort someone on a tour of something or some place. Please let me guide you around the plant, so you can see how we do things here.  I would be happy to guide you around.

dictionary.phrase: guide someone away from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to lead or escort someone away from someone, something, or some place. (Usually said of someone who requires help or guidance.) _ A police officer guided the children away from the busy street.  Please guide away those people before they bump into your grandmother.

to lead or escort someone away from someone, something, or some place. (Usually said of someone who requires help or guidance.) _ A police officer guided the children away from the busy street.  Please guide away those people before they bump into your grandmother.
to make something inoperable; to ruin someone’s plans.  Please, Bill, be careful and don’t gum up the works.  Tom sure gummed up the whole plan.
to make something inoperable; to ruin someone’s plans.  Please, Bill, be careful and don’t gum up the works.  Tom sure gummed up the whole plan.

to spout out of someone or something. (Can be words, water, blood, vomit, etc. The optional elements cannot be transposed.) _ The blood gushed forth from his wound.  Curses gushed forth from Sharon. Water gushed forth out of the broken pipe. The words gushed out from her mouth. The curses gushed from her mouth in torrents.

a personal, intuitive feeling or response.  I have a gut feeling that something bad is going to happen.  My gut reaction is that we should hire Susan for the job.

1. to cut or chop something out of something.  Jill hacked the bone out of the roast.  She hacked out the big bone. 2. to fashion something by carving or chiseling from something. He hacked a rabbit out of the chunk of wood.  In no time, the carver had hacked out a rabbit.

1. to cut or chop something out of something.  Jill hacked the bone out of the roast.  She hacked out the big bone. 2. to fashion something by carving or chiseling from something. He hacked a rabbit out of the chunk of wood.  In no time, the carver had hacked out a rabbit.

prefer to do something else; to be content to do something. (The would or had is usually expressed as the contraction ’d.) _They want me to go into town. I’d as soon stay home.  If you’re cooking stew tonight, we’d as soon eat somewhere else.  I would just as soon stay home as pay to go to see a bad movie.

prefer to do something. (The had is usually expressed as the contraction, ’d.) _ I’d rather go to town than sit here all evening.  They’d rather not.

dictionary.phrase: haggle (with someone) over someone or something
dictionary.definition: to argue with someone over someone or something. I don’t want to haggle with you over Tom and whose team he’s going to be on.  Let’s not haggle over the price.  There is no point in haggling with her.

dictionary.phrase: haggle with someone (over someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to argue with someone over someone or something. I don’t want to haggle with you over Tom and whose team he’s going to be on.  Let’s not haggle over the price.  There is no point in haggling with her.
to signal to a taxi that you want to be picked up.  See if you can hail a cab. I don’t want to walk home in the rain.
to signal to a taxi that you want to be picked up.  See if you can hail a cab. I don’t want to walk home in the rain.

to teach something to someone intensively, as if one were driving the information in by force.  Her parents had hammered good manners into her head since she was a child. They hammered in good manners every day.  They pounded proper behavior into the children.

Sl. to stand toward the front of a surfboard or diving board and hang the toes of one or both feet over the edge. (Surfing.) _The coach told her to hang ten and not to look down.  Get out there and hang five. You can swim. Nothing can go wrong.

to relax and stay calm. Just hang loose, man. Everything’ll be all right.  Stay loose, chum. See ya later.

to grasp someone or something.  She hung on to her husband to keep warm.  She sat there and hung on, trying to keep warm.

contented; very happy. (*Also: as ~.) _ I’ve been as happy as a clam since I moved to the country.  I don’t need much. Just somewhere to live, some work to do, and a TV to watch, and I’m happy as a clam at high tide. Matthew was happy as a lark throughout his whole vacation.  Bob was happy as can be when he won the lottery.

dictionary.phrase: a harbinger of things to come
dictionary.definition: a sample of the events that are to occur in the future. The first cuts in our budget are a harbinger of things to come.  Today’s visit from the auditors is a portent of things to come.

dictionary.phrase: a portent of things to come
dictionary.definition: a sample of the events that are to occur in the future. The first cuts in our budget are a harbinger of things to come.  Today’s visit from the auditors is a portent of things to come.

dictionary.phrase: a sign of things to come
dictionary.definition: a sample of the events that are to occur in the future. The first cuts in our budget are a harbinger of things to come.  Today’s visit from the auditors is a portent of things to come.
very hard. (*Also: as ~.) _ This cake is as hard as a rock! _ I can’t drive a nail into this wood. It’s hard as stone.
very hard. (*Also: as ~.) _ This cake is as hard as a rock! _ I can’t drive a nail into this wood. It’s hard as stone.
working hard at something.  Tom’s busy. He’s hard at work on the lawn.
working hard at something.  Tom’s busy. He’s hard at work on the lawn.
difficult person or problem to deal with.  This problem is getting me down. It’s a hard nut to crack.  Tom sure is a hard nut to crack. I can’t figure him out.
difficult person or problem to deal with.  This problem is getting me down. It’s a hard nut to crack.  Tom sure is a hard nut to crack. I can’t figure him out.
able to do something only with great difficulty.  I’m hard put to come up with enough money to pay the rent.  I get hard put like that about once a month.
able to do something only with great difficulty.  I’m hard put to come up with enough money to pay the rent.  I get hard put like that about once a month.
a very difficult time.  They had some hard sledding when they were first married.  It was tough sledding for sure when our crops failed that year.
a very difficult time.  They had some hard sledding when they were first married.  It was tough sledding for sure when our crops failed that year.
trouble [over something]; unnecessary difficulty. (*Typically: have ~; give someone ~.) _Please don’t give me a hard time.  The clerk got a hard time from the boss, so he quit.

not easily believed; hardly believable.  Her story was hard to swallow, and it finally was proven to be a lie.
not easily believed; hardly believable.  Her story was hard to swallow, and it finally was proven to be a lie.
to be very busy.  This was such a busy day. I hardly had time to breathe.  They made him work so hard that he scarcely had time to breathe.

to harass someone about something.  Come on! Don’t hassle me about the deadline! _ Stop hassling me with all the little details.

dictionary.phrase: haul something (from some place) to some place
dictionary.definition: to drag something from one place to another. I don’t want to have to haul this thing from home to office and back again.  I hauled my suitcase to the airport from my hotel.

dictionary.phrase: haul something from some place (to some place)
dictionary.definition: to drag something from one place to another. I don’t want to have to haul this thing from home to office and back again.  I hauled my suitcase to the airport from my hotel.
to stop somewhere; to come to rest somewhere. The car hauled up in front of the house.  My hat blew away just as the bus pulled up to the stop.
to stop somewhere; to come to rest somewhere. The car hauled up in front of the house.  My hat blew away just as the bus pulled up to the stop.

dictionary.phrase: have a clear conscience (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to be free of guilt about someone or something.  I’m sorry that John got the blame. I have a clean conscience about the whole affair.  I have a clear conscience about John and his problems. I didn’t do it. I swear to that with a clean conscience.

dictionary.phrase: have a clean conscience (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to be free of guilt about someone or something.  I’m sorry that John got the blame. I have a clean conscience about the whole affair.  I have a clear conscience about John and his problems. I didn’t do it. I swear to that with a clean conscience.
to have a narrow escape from something dangerous.  What a close shave I had! I nearly fell off the roof when I was working there.  I almost got struck by a speeding car. It was a close shave.
to have a narrow escape from something dangerous.  What a close shave I had! I nearly fell off the roof when I was working there.  I almost got struck by a speeding car. It was a close shave.

dictionary.phrase: have a corncob up one’s ass
dictionary.definition: 1. Inf. to be very stiff. (Use with caution.) _ How come you’re acting so high-and-mighty with me? Do you have a corncob up your ass? _ He was a terrible actor, stiff and wooden. He looked like he had a poker up his ass. 2. Inf. to be very touchy or irritable. Wow! Old Mr. Webster really has a corncob up his ass this morning. Watch out! _ Tom has a poker up his ass and he’s looking for you. Better make yourself scarce.

dictionary.phrase: have a poker up one’s ass

Old Mr. Webster really has a corncob up his ass this morning. Watch out! _ Tom has a poker up his ass and he’s looking for you. Better make yourself scarce.

dictionary.phrase: have a finger in the pie
dictionary.definition: to have a role in something; to be involved in something.  Tess wants to have a finger in the pie. She doesn’t think we can do it by ourselves.  Sally always wants to have a finger in the pie.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s finger in the pie
dictionary.definition: to have a role in something; to be involved in something.  Tess wants to have a finger in the pie. She doesn’t think we can do it by ourselves.  Sally always wants to have a finger in the pie.
to be very angry; to show great anger.  The teacher had a fit when the dog ran through the classroom.  John threw a fit when he found his car had been damaged.
to be very angry; to show great anger.  The teacher had a fit when the dog ran through the classroom.  John threw a fit when he found his car had been damaged.

Have a pleasant journey. (Compare this with Have a safe trip. This phrase avoids references to safety.) _ As Sue stepped onto the plane, someone in a uniform said, “Have a nice trip.” _ “Have a good trip,” said Bill, waving his good-byes.

to have talents or skills that no one knows about. Wow, Perry! I didn’t know you had so many hidden talents.
to have talents or skills that no one knows about. Wow, Perry! I didn’t know you had so many hidden talents.

dictionary.phrase: have a hunch (that something is the case)
dictionary.definition: to have an idea about what did, will, or should happen; to have a feeling that something will or should happen.  I had a hunch that you would be here when I arrived. I have a hunch about the way things will happen.

Sl. to be intoxicated. Fred has a load on and is finished drinking for the evening.  You have a load on every time I see you at a party.

Cliché an expression said when parting or saying good-bye. (This is now quite hackneyed, and many people are annoyed by it.) _ Clerk: Thank you. Tom: Thank you. Clerk: Have a nice day. Bob: See you, man! John: Bye, Bob. Have a good one!

to experience a difficult period.  Since his wife died, Mr. Brown has been having a rough time of it.  Be nice to Bob. He’s been having a rough time at work.

I hope that your journey is safe.; Be careful and assure that your journey is safe. (Said as someone is about to leave for a trip.) _ Bill: Well, we’re off for London. Sally: Have a safe trip. Bill: You’re driving all the way to San Francisco? Bob: Yes, indeed. Bill: Well, have a safe trip.

I hope that your journey is safe.; Be careful and assure that your journey is safe. (Said as someone is about to leave for a trip.) _ Bill: Well, we’re off for London. Sally: Have a safe trip. Bill: You’re driving all the way to San Francisco? Bob: Yes, indeed. Bill: Well, have a safe trip.
Inf. Fig. to be silly or eccentric.  He’s sort of strange. I think he’s got a loose screw.  Yes, he has a screw loose somewhere. He wears a heavy jacket in the middle of summer.

to have a romance or a love affair with someone. John and Mary have a thing going.  Bill has something going with Ann.
to have a romance or a love affair with someone. John and Mary have a thing going.  Bill has something going with Ann.

dictionary.phrase: have a tiger by the tail
dictionary.definition: to have become associated with something powerful and potentially dangerous; to have a very difficult problem to solve.  You have a tiger by the tail. You bit off more than you could chew.  You’ve had a bear by the tail ever since you agreed to finish that big project.

dictionary.phrase: have got a tiger by the tail
dictionary.definition: to have become associated with something powerful and potentially dangerous; to have a very difficult problem to solve.  You have a tiger by the tail. You bit off more than you could chew.  You’ve had a bear by the tail ever since you agreed to finish that big project.

dictionary.phrase: have a bear by the tail
dictionary.definition: to have become associated with something powerful and potentially dangerous; to have a very difficult problem to solve.  You have a tiger by the tail. You bit off more than you could chew.  You’ve had a bear by the tail ever since you agreed to finish that big project.
to be cowardly.  Tex has a yellow streak down his back a mile wide. He’s afraid to cross the street!

dictionary.phrase: have a yellow streak down one’s back
dictionary.definition: to be cowardly.  Tex has a yellow streak down his back a mile wide. He’s afraid to cross the street!
Euph. to be a drunkard.  He has an alcohol problem. It got so bad that he almost lost his job.  If you have a drinking problem, our clinic can help.
Euph. to be a drunkard.  He has an alcohol problem. It got so bad that he almost lost his job.  If you have a drinking problem, our clinic can help.

to have to rethink something because one was wrong the first time. (Think is a noun here.) _She’s quite wrong. She has another think coming if she wants to walk in here like that.  You have another guess coming if you think you can treat me like that!

to have other things to do; to have more important things to do.  I can’t take time for your problem. I have other fish to fry.  I won’t waste time on your question. I have bigger fish to fry.

dictionary.phrase: have more important fish to fry

dictionary.phrase: have calluses from patting one’s own back
dictionary.definition: to be a braggart.  If you haven’t heard about Bill’s latest achievement, he’d be glad to tell you. He has calluses from patting his own back.  Jane: I did a really wonderful job, if I do say so myself. Tom: If you’re not careful, you’ll break your arm patting yourself on the back.

dictionary.phrase: break one’s arm patting oneself on the back
dictionary.definition: to be a braggart.  If you haven’t heard about Bill’s latest achievement, he’d be glad to tell you. He has calluses from patting his own back.  Jane: I did a really wonderful job, if I do say so myself. Tom: If you’re not careful, you’ll break your arm patting yourself on the back.

dictionary.phrase: have half a notion to do something
dictionary.definition: to have almost decided to do something, especially something unpleasant. I have half a mind to go off and leave you here.  The cook had half a notion to serve cold chicken.

dictionary.phrase: have half a mind to do something
dictionary.definition: to have almost decided to do something, especially something unpleasant. I have half a mind to go off and leave you here.  The cook had half a notion to serve cold chicken.
to be mentally and physically organized; to be of sound mind.  I don’t have it all together today.  Try me again later when I have it all together.
to be mentally and physically organized; to be of sound mind.  I don’t have it all together today.  Try me again later when I have it all together.
to have succeeded; to be set for life.  I have a good job and a nice little family. I have it made.  He’s really got it made since he won the lottery.
to have succeeded; to be set for life.  I have a good job and a nice little family. I have it made.  He’s really got it made since he won the lottery.

dictionary.phrase: have it made in the shade
dictionary.definition: Sl. to have succeeded; to be set for life.  Wow, is he lucky! He has it made in the shade.  Sarah’s got it made in the shade with her huge inheritance.

dictionary.phrase: have got it made in the shade
dictionary.definition: Sl. to have succeeded; to be set for life.  Wow, is he lucky! He has it made in the shade.  Sarah’s got it made in the shade with her huge inheritance.

dictionary.phrase: have nothing to do with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to prefer not to associate or be associated with someone or something.  I don’t like Mike so I won’t have anything to do with the books he writes.  Bob will have nothing to do with Mary since she quit her job.

dictionary.phrase: not have anything to do with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to prefer not to associate or be associated with someone or something.  I don’t like Mike so I won’t have anything to do with the books he writes.  Bob will have nothing to do with Mary since she quit her job.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s ass in a sling
dictionary.definition: Sl. to be dejected or hurt; to be pouting. (Potentially offensive. Use only with discretion.) _ She’s got her ass in a sling because she got stood up.  So you didn’t get a perfect score. Why do you have your ass in a sling?

dictionary.phrase: have one’s cake and eat it too
dictionary.definition: Cliché to have in one’s possession something and be able to use or exploit it; to have it both ways. (Usually stated in the negative.) _ Tom wants to have his cake and eat it too. It can’t be done.  Don’t buy a car if you want to walk and stay healthy. You can’t eat your cake and have it too.

dictionary.phrase: eat one’s cake and have it too
dictionary.definition: Cliché to have in one’s possession something and be able to use or exploit it; to have it both ways. (Usually stated in the negative.) _ Tom wants to have his cake and eat it too. It can’t be done.  Don’t buy a car if you want to walk and stay healthy. You can’t eat your cake and have it too.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s hand in the till
dictionary.definition: to steal money from one’s employer. James couldn’t afford that car on just his salary. He must have his hand in the till.  Sally was outraged when she found that one of her salesclerks had his fingers in the till.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s finger(s) in the till
dictionary.definition: to steal money from one’s employer. James couldn’t afford that car on just his salary. He must have his hand in the till.  Sally was outraged when she found that one of her salesclerks had his fingers in the till.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s mind in the gutter
dictionary.definition: tending to think of or say things that are obscene.  Tiffany has her mind in the gutter. That’s why she laughs at all that dirty stuff.  Why do you tell so many dirty jokes? Do you always have your mind in the gutter.

dictionary.phrase: have got one’s mind in the gutter
dictionary.definition: tending to think of or say things that are obscene.  Tiffany has her mind in the gutter. That’s why she laughs at all that dirty stuff.  Why do you tell so many dirty jokes? Do you always have your mind in the gutter.

(More informal with druthers.) to have what one prefers; to have one’s way.  If I had my rathers, we’d go out every Friday night.  I suspect that if Joe had his druthers, he’d be taking Mary to the dance instead of Jill.

(More informal with druthers.) to have what one prefers; to have one’s way.  If I had my rathers, we’d go out every Friday night.  I suspect that if Joe had his druthers, he’d be taking Mary to the dance instead of Jill.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s shoulder to the wheel
dictionary.definition: to do the hard work that needs to be done; to focus on getting a job done.  You won’t accomplish anything unless you put your shoulder to the wheel. I put my shoulder to the wheel and finished the job quickly.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s shoulder to the wheel
dictionary.definition: to do the hard work that needs to be done; to focus on getting a job done.  You won’t accomplish anything unless you put your shoulder to the wheel. I put my shoulder to the wheel and finished the job quickly.

dictionary.phrase: pit one’s shoulder to the wheel
dictionary.definition: to do the hard work that needs to be done; to focus on getting a job done.  You won’t accomplish anything unless you put your shoulder to the wheel. I put my shoulder to the wheel and finished the job quickly.
Euph. to be drunk.  He had one too many, and now he’s throwing up.  You’d better not drive. I think you’ve had a few too many.
Euph. to be drunk.  He had one too many, and now he’s throwing up.  You’d better not drive. I think you’ve had a few too many.
to have enchanted or captivated the attention of someone.  She has him in her spell with her grace and beauty.  Ken has Karen under his spell.
to have enchanted or captivated the attention of someone.  She has him in her spell with her grace and beauty.  Ken has Karen under his spell.
to have someone or something nearby habitually.  I really don’t want to have all those people about all the time.  It’s good to have a fire extinguisher around.
to have someone or something nearby habitually.  I really don’t want to have all those people about all the time.  It’s good to have a fire extinguisher around.

dictionary.phrase: have someone or something on one’s mind
dictionary.definition: (More informal with brain.) to think often about someone or something; to be obsessed with someone or something. Bill has chocolate on his mind.  John has Mary on his mind every minute.  Karen has Ken on the brain.

dictionary.phrase: have someone or something on the brain
dictionary.definition: (More informal with brain.) to think often about someone or something; to be obsessed with someone or something. Bill has chocolate on his mind.  John has Mary on his mind every minute.  Karen has Ken on the brain.
to have something within (one’s) easy reach. (Have can be replaced with keep.) _ I have a dictionary at my fingertips.  I try to have everything I need at hand.
to have something within (one’s) easy reach. (Have can be replaced with keep.) _ I have a dictionary at my fingertips.  I try to have everything I need at hand.

dictionary.phrase: have something to do with something
dictionary.definition: to be associated with or related to something.  Does your dislike for Sally have something to do with the way she insulted you? _ My illness has something to do with my lungs.

dictionary.phrase: not have anything to do with something
dictionary.definition: to be associated with or related to something.  Does your dislike for Sally have something to do with the way she insulted you? _ My illness has something to do with my lungs.

dictionary.phrase: have nothing to do with something
dictionary.definition: to be associated with or related to something.  Does your dislike for Sally have something to do with the way she insulted you? _ My illness has something to do with my lungs.

to have a secret or surprise plan or solution (to a problem). (Alludes to cheating at cards by having a card hidden in one’s sleeve.) _I’ve got something up my sleeve, and it should solve all your problems. I’ll tell you what it is after I’m elected.  The manager has an ace up her sleeve. She’ll surprise us with it later.

dictionary.phrase: have an ace up one’s sleeve
dictionary.definition: to have a secret or surprise plan or solution (to a problem). (Alludes to cheating at cards by having a card hidden in one’s sleeve.) _I’ve got something up my sleeve, and it should solve all your problems. I’ll tell you what it is after I’m elected.  The manager has an ace up her sleeve. She’ll surprise us with it later.

dictionary.phrase: have the cards stacked against one
dictionary.definition: to have one’s chance at future success limited by factors over which one has no control; to have luck against one.  You can’t get very far in life if you have the deck stacked against you.  I can’t seem to get ahead. I always have the cards stacked against me.

dictionary.phrase: have the deck stacked against one
dictionary.definition: to have one’s chance at future success limited by factors over which one has no control; to have luck against one.  You can’t get very far in life if you have the deck stacked against you.  I can’t seem to get ahead. I always have the cards stacked against me.
Inf. to have a great deal of trouble. (Use hell with caution.) _ If you cheat on your income taxes, you’ll have the devil to pay.  I came home after three in the morning and had hell to pay.
Inf. to have a great deal of trouble. (Use hell with caution.) _ If you cheat on your income taxes, you’ll have the devil to pay.  I came home after three in the morning and had hell to pay.

to have a great facility with language; to be able to use language very effectively.  My brother really has the gift of gab. He can convince anyone of anything. I don’t talk a lot. I just don’t have the gift for gab.

to have a great facility with language; to be able to use language very effectively.  My brother really has the gift of gab. He can convince anyone of anything. I don’t talk a lot. I just don’t have the gift for gab.

dictionary.phrase: have the patience of a saint
dictionary.definition: to have a great deal of patience.  Steve has the patience of Job given the way his wife nags him. Dear Martha has the patience of a saint; she raised six children by herself.
to have a great deal of patience.  Steve has the patience of Job given the way his wife nags him. Dear Martha has the patience of a saint; she raised six children by herself.

to have done something (despite anything to the contrary). (This is an emphatic way of affirming that something has happened.) _ Mother: You haven’t made your bed. Bob: I have too! _ I have so turned in my paper! If you don’t have it, you lost it!

to have done something (despite anything to the contrary). (This is an emphatic way of affirming that something has happened.) _ Mother: You haven’t made your bed. Bob: I have too! _ I have so turned in my paper! If you don’t have it, you lost it!

dictionary.phrase: have too much on one’s plate
dictionary.definition: to be too busy. I’m sorry, I just have too much on my plate right now.  If you have too much on your plate, can I help?

dictionary.phrase: have a lot on one’s plate
dictionary.definition: to be too busy. I’m sorry, I just have too much on my plate right now.  If you have too much on your plate, can I help?
to have the skills, power, intelligence, etc., to do something.  I know I’ve got what it takes.  I guess I don’t have what it takes to be a composer.

Inf. a vague greeting asking about how someone has been occupied.  Tom: Been keeping busy? Bill: Yeah. Too busy.  Sue: Hi, Fred. Have you been keeping busy? Fred: Not really. Just doing what I have to.

Inf. a vague greeting asking about how someone has been occupied.  Tom: Been keeping busy? Bill: Yeah. Too busy.  Sue: Hi, Fred. Have you been keeping busy? Fred: Not really. Just doing what I have to.

Inf. a vague greeting asking about how someone has been occupied.  Tom: Been keeping busy? Bill: Yeah. Too busy.  Sue: Hi, Fred. Have you been keeping busy? Fred: Not really. Just doing what I have to.

Inf. an inquiry about how someone is surviving very hot weather.  Tom: What do you think of this hot weather? Been keeping cool? Sue: No, I like this weather just as it is.  Mary: Keeping cool? Bill: Yup. Run the air-conditioning all the time.

Inf. an inquiry about how someone is surviving very hot weather.  Tom: What do you think of this hot weather? Been keeping cool? Sue: No, I like this weather just as it is.  Mary: Keeping cool? Bill: Yup. Run the air-conditioning all the time.

dictionary.phrase: (Have you) been keeping out of trouble?
dictionary.definition: Inf. a vague greeting asking one what one has been doing.  Bob: Hi, Mary. Have you been keeping out of trouble? Mary: Yeah. And you? Bob: Oh, I’m getting by. Tom: Hey, man! Been keeping out of trouble? Bob: Hell, no! What are you up to? Tom: Nothing.

dictionary.phrase: (Have you been) keeping out of trouble?
dictionary.definition: Inf. a vague greeting asking one what one has been doing.  Bob: Hi, Mary. Have you been keeping out of trouble? Mary: Yeah. And you? Bob: Oh, I’m getting by. Tom: Hey, man! Been keeping out of trouble? Bob: Hell, no! What are you up to? Tom: Nothing.

dictionary.phrase: You been keeping out of trouble?
dictionary.definition: Inf. a vague greeting asking one what one has been doing.  Bob: Hi, Mary. Have you been keeping out of trouble? Mary: Yeah. And you? Bob: Oh, I’m getting by. Tom: Hey, man! Been keeping out of trouble? Bob: Hell, no! What are you up to? Tom: Nothing.

Inf. a vague greeting asking if one has been well.  Tom: Hey, man. How you doing? Bob: I’m okay. You been okay? Tom: Sure. See you! _Mary: I heard you were sick. Sally: Yes, but I’m better. Have you been okay? Mary: Oh, sure. Healthy as an ox.

Inf. a vague greeting asking if one has been well.  Tom: Hey, man. How you doing? Bob: I’m okay. You been okay? Tom: Sure. See you! _Mary: I heard you were sick. Sally: Yes, but I’m better. Have you been okay? Mary: Oh, sure. Healthy as an ox.

Have you decided to alter your decision? _ Sally: As of last week, they said you are leaving. Changed your mind? Bill: No. I’m leaving for sure. Tom: Well, have you changed your mind? Sally: Absolutely not!

a question used to introduce a piece of news or gossip.  Sally: Hi, Mary. Mary: Hi. Have you heard about Tom and Sue? Sally: No, what happened? Mary: I’ll let one of them tell you. Sally: Oh, come on! Tell me! _ Bob: Hi, Tom. What’s new? Tom: Did you hear that they’re raising taxes again? Bob: That’s not new.

dictionary.phrase: Haven’t I seen you somewhere before?
dictionary.definition: a polite or coy way of trying to introduce yourself to someone.  Bob: Hi. Haven’t I seen you somewhere before? Mary: I hardly think so.  Bill (moving toward Jane): Haven’t we met before? Jane (moving away from Bill): No way!

a polite or coy way of trying to introduce yourself to someone.  Bob: Hi. Haven’t I seen you somewhere before? Mary: I hardly think so.  Bill (moving toward Jane): Haven’t we met before? Jane (moving away from Bill): No way!

dictionary.phrase: He who laughs last, laughs longest.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If someone does something nasty to you, that person may feel satisfaction, but you will feel even more satisfaction if you get revenge on that person.  Joe pulled a dirty trick on me, but I’ll get him back. He who laughs last, laughs best.

dictionary.phrase: He who laughs last, laughs best.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If someone does something nasty to you, that person may feel satisfaction, but you will feel even more satisfaction if you get revenge on that person.  Joe pulled a dirty trick on me, but I’ll get him back. He who laughs last, laughs best.

One will be punished for one’s misdeeds.  Jill: It seems like Fred can do any evil thing he wants. Jane: Don’t worry. He’ll get his.  You may think you will always profit by your life of crime, but you’ll get yours.

to flee to higher ground.  The river’s rising. Head for the hills! _ Head for the hills! Here comes the f lood!

dictionary.phrase: a hell of a someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. Inf. a very bad person or thing. (Use caution with hell.) _That’s a hell of a way to treat someone. He’s a hell of a driver! Watch out! 2. Inf. a very good person or thing. (Use caution with hell.) _ He is one hell of a guy. We really like him.  We had a helluva good time.

1. Inf. a very bad person or thing. (Use caution with hell.) _That’s a hell of a way to treat someone. He’s a hell of a driver! Watch out! 2. Inf. a very good person or thing. (Use caution with hell.) _ He is one hell of a guy. We really like him.  We had a helluva good time.
to carve the shape of something out of something wooden. Dan hewed each of the posts out of a tree trunk.  He hewed out a number of posts.
to carve the shape of something out of something wooden. Dan hewed each of the posts out of a tree trunk.  He hewed out a number of posts.
very high. (*Also: as ~.) _ The tree grew as high as a kite.  Our pet bird got outside and f lew up high as the sky.

carelessly; aimlessly; without plan or direction. There was no planning. It was justs hit and miss.  We handed out the free tickets hit or miss. Some people got one. Others got five or six.

to really make sense; [for a comment] to make a very good point.  Mary’s criticism of my clothes hit home, so I changed.  The teacher’s comment struck home and the student vowed to work harder.

to affect one personally and intimately.  Her comments really hit me where I live. Her words seemed to apply directly to me.  I listened carefully and didn’t think she hit close to home at all.

Inf. Fig. to study hard.  I spent the weekend pounding the books.  I gotta go home and hit the books. I have finals next week.

Inf. to go on a drinking bout; to get drunk.  Jed’s hitting the bottle again.  He’s been hitting the booze for a week now.

1. Fig. Inf. to start walking; to go into the streets.  I have a long way to go. I’d better hit the bricks.  Go on! Hit the pavement! Get going! 2. Inf. Fig. to go out on strike. The workers hit the pavement on Friday and haven’t been back on the job since.  Agree to our demands, or we hit the bricks.

1. Fig. Inf. to start walking; to go into the streets.  I have a long way to go. I’d better hit the bricks.  Go on! Hit the pavement! Get going! 2. Inf. Fig. to go out on strike. to get very angry.  She really hit the ceiling when she found out what happened.  My dad’ll hit the roof when he finds out that I wrecked his car.
to get very angry.  She really hit the ceiling when she found out what happened.  My dad’ll hit the roof when he finds out that I wrecked his car.
to go to bed.  I have to go home and hit the hay pretty soon. Let’s hit the sack. We have to get an early start in the morning.

to panic suddenly.  She hit the panic button and just went to pieces.  Don’t press the panic button. Relax and keep your eyes open.

everywhere; here, there, and everywhere. (Formal and archaic.) _ The prince looked hither, thither, and yon for the beautiful woman who had lost the glass slipper.  The terrible wizard had sown the seeds of his evil vine hither, thither, and yon. Soon the evil, twisted plants began to sprout in all the land.

to be in a favorable position; to be in a controlling position. (Alludes to having possession of all four aces or all the high cards in a card game.) _ How can I advance in my career when my competitor holds all the aces? _If I held all the aces, I’d be able to do great things.  I tried to get my points across, but Joan held all the cards and the board voted for her plan.

Stop right there!; Wait a minute! (Minute can be replaced by moment, second, or other time periods.) _ Bob: Hold on, Tom. Tom: What? Bob: I want to talk to you.  “Hold on!” hollered Tom. “You’re running off with my shopping cart!”

dictionary.phrase: hold one’s end of the bargain up†
dictionary.definition: to do one’s part as agreed; to attend to one’s responsibilities as agreed.  If you don’t hold your end up, the whole project will fail.  Tom has to learn to cooperate. He must keep up his end of the bargain.

dictionary.phrase: keep one’s end of the bargain up†
dictionary.definition: to do one’s part as agreed; to attend to one’s responsibilities as agreed.  If you don’t hold your end up, the whole project will fail.  Tom has to learn to cooperate. He must keep up his end of the bargain.
to consider someone responsible for something; to blame something on someone. I hold you accountable for John’s well-being.  I must hold you responsible for the missing money.
to consider someone responsible for something; to blame something on someone. I hold you accountable for John’s well-being.  I must hold you responsible for the missing money.

dictionary.phrase: hold someone or something in reserve
dictionary.definition: to hold back someone or something for future needs.  I am holding the frozen desserts in reserve, in case we run out of cake.  We are holding Sharon in reserve.  Keep a few good players in reserve.

dictionary.phrase: keep someone or something in reserve
dictionary.definition: to hold back someone or something for future needs.  I am holding the frozen desserts in reserve, in case we run out of cake.  We are holding Sharon in reserve.  Keep a few good players in reserve.

dictionary.phrase: hold someone or something out (of something)
dictionary.definition: to set someone or something aside from the rest; to prevent someone or a group from participating. Her parents held her out of sports because of her health.  They held out every player who had an injury.
